title.narrative: COMMUNITY BASED SEA TURTLE RESTORATION PROGRAM IN BANGLADESH.

description.narrative: The recipient will; 1) train community members to conduct nesting beach surveys and nest protection along the 250 km coast of Cox's Bazar and Parki beach and expand to all suitable beaches on coastline; 2) conduct foraging habitat and bycatch surveys; 3) promote an important nesting site for a Nature Reserve; 4) prepare educational and outreach materials and conduct education and awareness program with local communities; and 5) establish a sea turtle rehabilitation center.

title.narrative: Working with the Government of Bangladesh to Strengthen Their Compliance with CITES CoP17.Decisions

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to counter wildlife trafficking in Bangladesh by strengthening the capacity of the Government of Bangladesh (GoB) to implement decisions of CITES CoP17 regarding international trade, particularly of Indian Pangolins (Manis crassicaudata), Silky sharks Carcharhinus falciformis), Thresher sharks (Alopias spp.) and Mobula rays (Mobula spp.), species that were recently included in CITES Appendix I or II with the co-sponsorship of the Government of Bangladesh (GoB). Specific activities will include: (1) conducting seminars with senior officials from the Forest Department, National Police, Fisheries Department, Customs, Border Guards, Rapid Action Battalion and Coast Guard about CITES CoP17 decisions and on the illegal trade of CITES Appendix I and II species in Bangladesh, consult with them about knowledge gaps on trade in these species, and at the end of the project rigorously evaluate progress and formulate recommendations for next steps; (2) conducting intensive training workshops on CITES regulations and enforcement emphasizing the CITES Appendices and obligations under the treaty, including CITES CoP17 decisions, with field-level officers from these same government agencies; (3) developing and providing resource materials to these same agencies on national laws and CITES decisions on wildlife trade and the identification of CITES Appendix I and II species; (4) providing follow-up mentoring support for these agencies on lessons learned during the wildlife trade workshops; (5) working with the Forest Department to strengthen their Wildlife Crime Database to ensure that it includes Indian Pangolins, Silky sharks, Thresher sharks and Mobula rays as well as other CITES Appendix I and II species; and (6) using seminars, training workshops, follow up mentoring visits, and work on strengthening the Wildlife Trade Database to facilitate communication among GoB agencies on enforcing national wildlife laws and CITES regulations and on increasing

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: Protecting tigers in the Bangladesh Sundarbans through strengthened SMART patrols and improved understanding of wildlife crimes

description.narrative: The main threat to tigers and their prey in the Bangladesh Sundarbans is poaching. Enhancing law enforcement and strengthening the capacity of the frontline staff to reduce and eliminate threats to tigers are immediate priorities for securing tiger populations in their source sites. A Spatial Monitoring and Reporting Tool (SMART) has been proven to be an effective tool in collecting information on threats to species and their habitat. The Bangladesh Forest Department (BFD) is implementing SMART wildlife enforcement and monitoring patrols with technical support from WCS Bangladesh. Project objectives are to, (1) Map high risk areas and assess spatial and temporal patterns of illegal activity affecting tigers and their prey using data from SMART patrols and camera trapping; (2) Establish a long-term system for monitoring threats to tigers and their prey based on SMART data and camera traps set in strategic locations; and, (3) Support the SMART patrolling teams to achieve zero poaching of tigers and their prey in the Sundarbans.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: Protecting tigers in the Bangladesh Sundarbans through strengthened SMART patrols and improved understanding of wildlife crimes

description.narrative: The main threat to tigers and their prey in the Bangladesh Sundarbans is poaching. Enhancing law enforcement and strengthening the capacity of the frontline staff to reduce and eliminate threats to tigers are immediate priorities for securing tiger populations in their source sites. A Spatial Monitoring and Reporting Tool (SMART) has been proven to be an effective tool in collecting information on threats to species and their habitat. The Bangladesh Forest Department (BFD) is implementing SMART wildlife enforcement and monitoring patrols with technical support from WCS Bangladesh. Project objectives are to, (1) Map high risk areas and assess spatial and temporal patterns of illegal activity affecting tigers and their prey using data from SMART patrols and camera trapping; (2) Establish a long-term system for monitoring threats to tigers and their prey based on SMART data and camera traps set in strategic locations; and, (3) Support the SMART patrolling teams to achieve zero poaching of tigers and their prey in the Sundarbans.

title.narrative: COMMUNITY BASED SEA TURTLE RESTORATION PROGRAM IN BANGLADESH

description.narrative: This project will implement a sea turtle conservation program in Bangladesh. The intent is to address threats from poaching of eggs and accidental capture and mortality in coastal gill net and trawl fisheries. Activities include: 1) training community members to conduct nesting beach surveys and nest protection along the 250 km coast of Cox's Bazar and Parki beach; 2)working with fisherman to implement best practices to reduce sea turtle capture, injury and mortality; 3) preparing educational and outreach materials and conducting education and awareness programs with local communities, fisherman and schools; and 4) complete construction of a sea turtle rehabilitation center for turtles injured by boats or accidental capture in nets or trawls and will also serve as an education center for local people and attraction for tourists.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

title.narrative: COMMUNITY BASED SEA TURTLE RESTORATION PROGRAM IN BANGLADESH

description.narrative: Expand sea turtle monitoring and Conservation from current 250 kms to all suitable beaches of entire 710 kms Bangladesh coastline, Habitat Restoration like beach and underwater foraging area, Reduction of sea turtle bycatch, at least 30%, as currently still 5-6 turtle caught/year. Develop capacity of 500 people including Conservation Assistant (CA), fishers, GO officials, educate more than 20 thousand visitors and students along the coastal area.

title.narrative: PROTECTING TIGERS IN THE BANGLADESH SUNDARBANS THROUGH STRENGTHENED SMART PATROLS AND BETTER DETECTION AND UNDERSTANDING OF WILDLIFE CRIME

description.narrative: Empower the Bangladesh Forest Department to better protect tigers where they occur in the highest.densities and face the greatest risk of being poached in the Sundarbans, Bangladesh, through improved.understanding of the spatial and temporal distribution of threats and strengthened conservation.management and awareness.
